description:
Hi Everyone,

 

1) I'm completely open to suggestions for this next meetup. I have selected a meeting place with wi-fi but the meet-up will take place in a Google Hangout that will be organized either by myself "[masked]" or by another meetup member.

 

2) Is anyone interested in leading this group? I would love to see the Android developer community growing in the greater SL Valley and to see an involved community that will help its members grow as developers with mentorship, basic training, tips and tricks, and generally being a resource to each other.

 

3) My personal interest is to see a group be formed and to help when possible. I do not have Android developer experience.

 

Welcome your comments and ideas.

 

-reza

description:
We'll talk about our move to be part of and under the Google Developer Group (GDG Utah).

Experienced Android developers, come and learn what we'll be able to do with the support of Google.

Pizza dinner at 6:30pm

name: Start our first app project
description:
Agenda:

Talk about: our new name, wearables, TV, Internet of Things

Projects:

We will begin discussion and team-forming to build our first group project.

The candidate project is this:

An app for the blind. It connects a blind person with a sighted volunteer via Google hangout. A volunteer will be able to indicate: available or not right now; schedule when available and when not. A volunteer is either a dispatcher or a narrator. As a dispatcher, a volunteer answers a call from a user and types in what the user is requesting; e.g. "I'm on a bus and would like to hear about what I'm passing" and the dispatcher will then submit the request to the pool of available volunteers. 

The first volunteer to reply will get connected to the user.

The volunteer and user will be on an audio/video hangout.

Either the volunteer or the user can stop the hangout and for a short period of time, say 10 minutes, able to re-initiate the hangout in case of an accidental disconnect.

Other details and design goals to be discussed. 

We welcome a cross-meetup effort including Javascript, Web developers, and designers.

Thank you to Instructure. Food will be provided by Instructure.

name: Come learn about PhoneGap (aka Apache Cordova) for building cross-device apps
description:
At this meetup, we'll learn about PhoneGap from its creator. How often do we get a chance like that? While this meetup won't be strictly about Android development, it is related. Phone Gap (or Apache Cordova) lets you build an app for Android, iOS, Windows, Firefox OS, Kindle... and you write your program in Javascript and use HTML and CSS for rendering. How can that be, you ask? Joe Bowser will tell us.

About the talk:

The original purpose of PhoneGap (see Apache Cordova) back in its inception in 2008 was for it to no longer be needed. The belief was that HTML/CSS and Javascript would eventually become first class citizens and would be one of the primary ways that people would develop applications. However, despite numerous changes, there is even more activity around Apache Cordova than there ever has in the past.

This talk will go through what is possible today using HTML5, CSS and Javascript with and without Apache Cordova, what still needs work, where the future is heading, and how you can help.

This will also cover some of the different ways that one can use Cordova, and is a good introductory talk on the differences between a pure HTML5 application, a Hybrid Application, a fully native application, and why none of these distinctions should matter to your users.

Speaker:

Joe Bowser
Adobe Systems

Joe is the creator of PhoneGap for Android and is the longest contributing committer to the PhoneGap and Apache Cordova projects respectively. When he is not contributing to Open Source at Adobe, he spends his spare time working on various hardware projects at home, as well as at the Vancouver Hack Space, which he co-founded.

Please arrive by 6 pm,

Talk to start @ 6 pm
followed by discussion and open Q&A

Dinner provided.

We will meet in the room named "Michelangelo" on the same level that you enter, where main reception is. Dinner provided.

name: Idiomatic Dart (and Chrome Packaged Apps)
description:
Dart is a cohesive, scalable platform for building apps that run on the Web (where you can use Polymer or Angular) or on servers (such as with Google Cloud Platform). Use the Dart language, libraries, and tools to write anything from simple scripts to full-featured apps.

Dart was designed to look and feel familiar if you’re coming from other languages, in particular Java and JavaScript. If you try hard enough, you can use Dart just like it was one of those languages. But Dart has a number of superpowers that, when used correctly, make your code look and feel like idiomatic Dart. From design patterns to syntactic sugar, we'll explore the language features that set Dart apart from lesser Web languages. This exploration should also serve as a great intro to Dart code for those who are unfamiliar with it.

As a bonus, we'll have an opening presentation about creating Chrome Packaged Apps with Dart.

Remember: The meetup will be held on the basement level of the Orem Public Library in the media auditorium.

name: More Idiomatic Dart
description:
It went so well last time, we decided to do it again! In December's meetup, we covered Dart syntax for the very basics, including types, variables, functions, enums, and string interpolation. This time, we'll get into the things that make Dart a great OOP (object-oriented programming) language, like classes, inheritance, mixins, constructors, getters and setters, privacy, and Dart's library module system. Time permitting, we'll start talking about Streams and Futures, two of Dart's core concepts that help make it the incredible Web language that it is.

Also on the agenda are bonus presentations from a few of our members, so come prepared to be dazzled!

name: Even More Idiomatic Dart
description:
And we continue with our riveting series on idiomatic ways to use the Dart Web language to construct apps that run in the browser, on the desktop, and on the server. In the past few installments, we covered the very basics, and we even started talking just a little bit about object-oriented programming with Dart.

This month, we'll dive more deeply into OOP with Dart, including a review of the different kinds of constructors, and advanced use of getters and setters. We'll talk about Streams and how Dart uses them to unify event models. Time permitting, we'll get into Futures (promises), as well, which is how Dart handles asynchronous programming and saves devs from JavaScript's infamous "callback hell".

This month we’ll have guest presenter Charles Nielson presenting on using Dart and Polymer in production. Charles uses Dart professionally and will show us a live app he created for his line of work using Dart.

Note: Yeah, we're still at the library this month (heh). Remember, it's on the basement level in the media auditorium.

name: More Dart
description:
Dart is a better way to develop Web apps! Hang out with us to find out why.

This month, we'll continue to dig deep into Dart's support for object-oriented programming, including inheritance, polymorphism, interfaces, abstract classes, and more. This will be followed by open discussions about what's happened in the world of Dart over the last month and where things seem to be headed. Other topics will be flexible, though they might include project architecture, Dart on the server, Dart's tools and core libraries, Polymer, Streams and Futures, or anything else our members would like to talk about.

As ever, we may or may not be graced by additional presentations from others in our community, and I'll update this space as news on that becomes more concrete.

Big news: A new venue! This month, we'll be meeting at the Small Business Development Center of Utah Valley University. If this sounds daunting, it's not. Easy to find, right off the freeway, good parking, desks and outlets for everyone...should be great.

Our group will be meeting in the Front Conference Room (BR 102). Just as you enter the building, the room is on the right.

name: Dart: Types and Generics
description:
Types and generics are two of the concepts that help make Dart the best tool to create Web apps. Even with JS ES6 on the (distant) horizon, Dart remains the superior choice for a host of reasons. We'll go over how Dart's type system works in great detail, so that you can use it to maximum benefit as you create your Web-based or server-side masterpieces.

As ever, there may be guest presentations, and I'll update this space with any announcements about that.

Big news: Google has announced that they will not be incorporating the Dart virtual machine directly into the Chrome browser. Quite a blow, but is that the end of Dart? Far from it. In fact, the team's new focus on making Dart the very best compile-to-JS language available might be a net win for everyone. Dart's interoperability with JavaScript is about to improve dramatically. We'll talk more about this significant development at our meetup, as well.

Location: Our group will be meeting in the Front Conference Room (BR 102). Just as you enter the building, the room is on the right. There will be signs.

name: GDG Web May Meetup
description:
Join us for our may meetup. This month we have a special guest speaker, +Ryan Gifford, who will be presenting to us about container-ization and google kubernetes. Ryan Gifford was part of the team at Mozy/EMC on the new Cloud Protective Services which leverages docker and kubernetes to bring continuous deployment, and cloud scalability to the service.

name: Dart on the Server
description:
Move over, Node! Dart works for server and console apps too! Bring all of the advantages of Dart in the browser to the server side, but without the need to compile to JavaScript. Like JS on Node, Dart running in its own virtual machine is event-driven, asynchronous, and allows you to build a client-server app all in one language, but Dart's immutable objects and simpler semantics give it a huge speed boost over V8.

Join us, and work along, as we show you just how easy it is to put up a simple Web server with Dart's popular Redstone framework, complete with custom routing, and--time permitting--WebSocket support.

Big News: Many of the group's organizers and members attended the Dart Developer Summit at Google's San Francisco offices, and hopefully some of you caught the live streams online. We'll spend some time recapping the highlights.

Prizes: At the end of the meet there will be a short survey. Give us a little feedback and be entered to win awesome prizes from Google's quarterly give-away! The winner will get to choose a prize: a Nexus 9 tablet, an Acer 13 Chromebook, or an LG G Watch R.

Location: Our group will be meeting in the Front Conference Room (BR 102). Just as you enter the building, the room is on the right. There will be signs.

name: Writing Command-Line Utilities with Dart
description:
If there's one thing computers are good for, it's automating repetitive, tedious startup tasks that waste developers' time and, in the worst cases, serve as a deterrent to starting a project at all. Writing a few small scripts to handle the boilerplate and scaffolding can go a long way toward eliminating barriers to productivity.

Using Dart to create these scripts brings all the usual advantages: stellar tooling and high productivity, integrated debugging and profiling, and syntax and semantics built to help you move fast and scale up.

Join us, and work along, as we walk you through setting up a Dart development environment, creating a simple command-line app, and registering the app for global access on your system.

Big News: Our intrepid organizer, Monty Rasmussen, spent the last week of May at the GDG Global Summit and Google I/O 2015. We'll spend a few minutes going over the pertinent highlights.

Prizes: At the end of the meet there will be a short survey. Give us a little feedback and be entered to win awesome prizes from Google's quarterly give-away! The winner will get to choose a prize: a Nexus 9 tablet, an Acer 13 Chromebook, or an LG G Watch R.

Location: Our group will be meeting in the Front Conference Room (BR 102). Just as you enter the building, the room is on the right. There will be signs.

name: 2 Android tracks: New and Intermediate+
description:
In our last meeting we decided that a repeating format would be useful. The planned format is to have two tracks, one as orientation for Android beginners and another for experienced Android developers. Food is not provided at this meetup, but you are able to eat food in the conference room where we meet.

Location info: As you come to Instructure tonight please note a few things. 1. Please park on the ground level and enter the giant glass doors. (This is the 2nd floor) Elevators are to the right. There will be no way to get into the building after 6:30. The doors will become locked. 2. Please come up to the 7th floor. From there you will walk down some stairs to the 6th floor where we will be meeting. We will have signs posted.

Track 1: Beginner Orientation @ 6:15pm. Build an Android app from scratch. Bring a laptop or follow along with a fellow developer.

import introductionToAndroid;

String event = "Hello World!";

For those interested in learning and trying things out. Here is the suggested preparation:

Download and install Android Studio:

http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html

Download the SDKs you wish to work with. They can be downloaded within the SDK manager of Android Studio. Also download the Google USB driver which is also found in the SDK manager.

There is WiFi, but these downloads are large and will take some time, so anything you can download ahead of time would be helpful. If you have an Android device, bring it along with a USB cable.

Track 2: 6:15pm, discussion and open Q&A

We will be brainstorming ideas for an app for the group to continually develop. Also, bring your own apps-in-progress and get help or ideas.

Ideas:
Android and the Internet of Things
UI tips: how does Flipboard do it?
Making Uber
An app with payments
An app to count your steps
App analytics
Managing users across more than 1 app
Differences between Android and iOS

name: Web Games with Dart and the HTML5 Canvas
description:
Enough of the serious stuff. Let's have some fun! This month, we're going to leave behind the CRUD apps, business logic, and daily stand-ups. We'll explore how features like real classes, comprehensive standard libraries, and syntactic sugar make Dart the perfect technology for producing browser-based games. Over the course of the meetup, we'll build a simple action game together, exploring concepts like drawing on the HTML5 canvas, random number generation, and game loops using one of the modern browsers' hottest new features, requestAnimationFrame().

Perhaps best of all for those of you new to Dart: all the game code we write can be composed and executed in the online Dart playground, DartPad (http://dartpad.dartlang.org). No setup required! Just bring any device that can run a modern web browser and you're good to go. Of course, if you already use a full-fledged editing environment like WebStorm, Eclipse, or Sublime Text, those will work too.

Big News: Dart 1.11 was released! We'll spend a few minutes talking about the changes and new features.

Prizes: At the end of the meet there will be a short survey. Give us a little feedback and be entered to win awesome prizes from Google's quarterly give-away! The winner will get to choose a prize: a Nexus 9 tablet, an Acer 13 Chromebook, or an LG G Watch R.

Location: Our group will be meeting in the Front Conference Room (BR 102). Just as you enter the building, the room is on the right. There will be signs.

name: Build something in Android
description:
This is a chance for anyone with any level of Android experience to build, improve, test, or revamp an app.

We'll start with a presentation by Matt, the lead Android developer at Instructure, on how to approach the app designing process, and then break off into individual groups to work on whatever you brought. We'll be glad to help you install the SDK and write a simple "Hello World" app, talk about monetization, testing, analytics, gaining users, fix bugs, anything! Also feel free to get up and present a lightning talk about what you are working on.

Agenda:
Pizza and Introductions from 6 to 6:30
Matt's Presentation 6:30 to 7ish
Work on apps, lightning talks 7 to 8ish

name: GDG Web Family Night and Birthday Party!
description:
Hey everyone! We have a super fun and exciting event planned for this month! Please bring your family and celebrate GDG's Utah's 6th year with us! Our own Bob Dunn is going to be doing an amazing presentation on working with Spheros and introducing your family to programming with hardware! In addition to this we will also be celebrating GDG Utahs birthday with cake and pizza!

As always food will start at 6:30 and the presentations start at 7! We hope to see you with your families there! ﻿

name: Real-Time Chat with Dart and Firebase
description:
A real-time, multi-user chat application in under 30 lines of code and no server? But how? Dart, with its comprehensive core libraries and well-honed syntax, combined with the awesome power of Firebase, a NoSQL, ultra-fast, online database system! If you've ever wondered about using Dart for web apps or Firebase for databases, don't miss this opportunity to create your own app using both, as we walk you through it step-by-step. And did I mention you don't even have to write any server-side code...? Awesome.

This month we'll also have a bonus presentation on using the latest version of Bootstrap with Dart, given by our newest GDG UT organizer, Rachel Ward. Don't miss it.

Prizes: At the end of the meet there will be a short survey. Give us a little feedback and be entered to win awesome prizes from Google's quarterly giveaway! The winner will get to choose a prize: a Nexus 9 tablet, an Acer 13 Chromebook, or an LG G Watch R.

Additionally, we're talking to the Firebase guys about some Firebase swag and/or promo codes. We'll update this space as things develop.

Update: Firebase is in! We should have some official Firebase paraphernalia at the event.

Location: Our group will be meeting in the Front Conference Room (BR 102). Just as you enter the building, the room is on the right. There will be signs.

name: Web Games with Dart and CSS Flexbox: Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe
description:
Let's build a game! Ever played Tic-Tac-Toe? Sucks, right? It's not even ultimate. But Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe is! Join us as we guide you through the process of creating your very own web version of this great game using your favorite JavaScript alternative, Dart. We'll be using the new CSS Flexbox technique for layout. It'll be functional, it'll be object-oriented, and it'll be fun.

Bonus: This month's code will all run right in DartPad. No need for any setup! Just fire up a web browser and start coding.

Prizes: At the end of the meet there will be a short survey. Give us a little feedback and be entered to win awesome prizes from Google's quarterly giveaway! The winner will get to choose a prize: a Nexus 9 tablet, an Acer 13 Chromebook, or an LG G Watch R.

As always pizza starts at 6:30! Bring your friends and we will see you there!

description:
We'll talk about how to install and build a basic Android app. Please bring a laptop if you have one and download and install Android Studio and the Android SDK ahead of time, if possible. If you have an existing app, bring it and any questions and we'll tackle those as well.

name: Polymer Dart Code Lab: Your First Elements
description:
Dart! Polymer! Web components! Buzz words! Learn the facts behind the hype. Can you really build new HTML elements for your web apps? Why would you want to? How is it done? In this code lab, we'll briefly go over the background of these new technologies and, together, build a simple Polymer Dart web application to gently introduce some of the key concepts.

Bonus: Even though we'll be using the Dart language to demonstrate the concepts, anyone who's interested in using PolymerJS (Polymer for JavaScript) will find the majority of the material directly relevant.

Setup: We'll try to spend some time up front getting everyone's development environments rolling, but if you want to get a head start, pull up the Dart Tools page and grab the SDK, Dartium, and an IDE or editor.

description:

With Polymer custom HTML elements and data binding, you'll see that it's possible to put together an advanced application using little or no imperative (Dart or JavaScript) code.

Bonus: Even though we'll be using the Dart language to demonstrate the concepts, anyone who's interested in using PolymerJS (Polymer for JavaScript) will find the majority of the material directly relevant.

Setup: We'll try to spend some time up front getting everyone's development environments rolling, but if you want to get a head start, pull up the Dart Tools page and grab the SDK, Dartium, and an IDE or editor.

description:

Each situation is different, so we're taking 3 of the most prominent approaches so that you can learn the ups and downs of each. Tell your friends and coworkers to RSVP and join us!

Three speakers will address us about different approaches to cross platform development! Stephen Spann (mobilecpptutorials.com) will talk about C++ solutions for mobile development via Skype. Stephen Shaw (xamarin.com) will talk about using C# and the Xamarin framework. Mike Hartington from the Ionic Framework team (ionic.io) will talk about their product which uses Javascript, HTML5, and CSS.

name: Learn by Doing: Firebase + Android

venue.name: The Iron Yard

description:

While not a drop-in replacement, it can serve as an affordable (incl. free tier), scalable, low-maintenance backend for Android, iOS, and web apps. We are going to begin with a quick intro to Firebase, and then follow a codelab to implement a Firebase backend for an existing Android sample app that plays the Hangman game. Also, I've gotten in touch with a local Google Developer Expert on Firebase who will be addressing our group in the future. This is a chance to get your feet wet by completing a Firebase-backed project in a single night so that we are ready for a more advanced discussion later. You’ll have access to Google experts on various cloud topics plus get to know the local Google team responsible for Google’s cloud offering in SLC. We look forward to seeing you on the September 8th.

description:

More about Chris: "Chris got his start in the financial industry, but after the crash of 2008, he taught himself how to program and transitioned to a career in front-end web development. He and his wife Melissa Esplin have run Calligraphy.org full-time since 2013. He's a Google Developer Expert for Firebase, publishing Firebase instructional articles and videos all over the web."

Pizza at 6:30
Presentation at 7
Questions throughout

name: Chromecast V3 for Web and Mobile
description:
Jarom McDonald is a Google Developer Expert in web technologies and will present on the latest updates to Chromecast. Google has released v3 of Chromecast sender libraries for mobile and web. It simplifies the process pretty dramatically.

Jarom is VidAngel’s director of engineering and lead streaming engineer. He left behind the high-risk life of a tenured university professor so he could live with the security, peace-of-mind, and short workdays of entrepreneurship. As director of engineering, he manages the streaming technologies, infrastructure, and playback experience; is a member of the Google Developer Experts ecosystem; and specializes in web app and web media consultation – so good thing he has a PhD in American literature.

In his previous job, he managed 90 people across 9 different academic departments. He currently manages 5 children in 1 family (his own).

We are going to work as a group to create it! Come join us in the spirit of Christmas and helping others to really make a difference in the lives of these refugees. If you don't know how to do Android development still come! There will be ways for everyone to get involved! As always pizza starts at 6:30 and we will start at 7:00!

name: Humanitarian Hack Day

venue.name: Google Fiber Space Salt Lake City

description:
Hey Everyone! This months meetup is actually going to be a hack day! We are going to continue on the app we talked about in our last meetup and build it! 

For those of you who didn't attend last month, this app is a humanitarian project for refugees. It's an app that will allow them to call for help if they are being bullied or harassed (which the frequency of that happening is increasing by the day). This is an amazing cause that will help A LOT of people so please join us in building it!

Food of course will be provided! See you all there!

In the meantime, feel free to contribute at https://github.com/utahopensource/tgg_SAFE, or the Pull Request/Forked repo at cantocass's github.

name: Building an Android app from scratch
description:

name: How to get started with Machine Learning
description:
With I/O coming up we wanted to touch on something we expect to be featured prominently: Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence. We'll broadly cover three ways to get started with ML:
The first way is to use “ready to use” APIs, like Cloud Vision.
These are powered by machine learning, but you can take advantage of them without needing to know all the details
The second way is to use an existing model, and retrain it with your data.
For example, say you wanted to train a model to recognize your own images
One way to do this is to use TensorFlow, an open source library for machine learning
You could start with an existing model, like Inception, and train it with your own data
We’ll see an example of how to do this using TensorFlow for Poets later on
Finally, you can use TensorFlow to develop your own algorithms

name: Google I/O Recap
description:
Brett Tucker, one of Pluralsight's Android Engineers, is going to give us a run through of everything that happened at I/O.

Pizza served at 6:30, content starts at 7.

name: What's New in Android Testing Support Library 1.0
description: Join us for a fun and exciting overview of what's new in Android Testing Support Library 1.0 (or "ATSL" for short), which was just announced on July 25th. This talk will give a basic overview for those who are newer to Android development, as well as delving deeper into some of the more advanced features that ATSL has to offer. Bring your friends! :-)

name: Explore Android Things (IoT) and TensorFlow (ML) with simple hardware by Cassidy
description:
We are going to use the TensorFlow library for Android to build a device that captures images from the IoT device camera and locally classifies them against a pre-trained ImageNet model.

Android Things makes developing connected embedded devices easy by providing the same Android development tools, best-in-class Android framework, and Google APIs that make developers successful on mobile. With the TensorFlow inference library for Android, developers can easily integrate TensorFlow and machine learning into their apps on Android Things.

TensorFlow™ is an open source software library for numerical computation using data flow graphs. Nodes in the graph represent mathematical operations, while the graph edges represent the multidimensional data arrays (tensors) communicated between them. TensorFlow has become a popular framework for training machine learning models and using those models to solve problems.

We'll serve Pizza provided by our sponsor, TekSystems, at 6:30, the talk will start at 7.

The Google Development Group Salt Lake is sponsored by Google and the meeting space is provided by our sponsor HireVue.

Jordan Hansen has been developing with Kotlin since version 0.8, and he as released 7+ applications using the language. He has also contributed to the Kotlin source code.
https://github.com/hansenji

We'll serve Pizza provided by our sponsor, TEKSystems, at 6:30 P.M., the talk will start at 7 P.M.

The Google Development Group Salt Lake is sponsored by Google, Inc. and the meeting space is provided by HireVue, our sponsor. We will raffle off one paid license to any IntelliJ product at the end of the evening, so be sure to RSVP!

name: Holiday Party and Hack Night
description: We are throwing our first Holiday Party! No specific agenda, feel free to bring a laptop and wrap up a side project, or just enjoy the food and stick around for the raffle at the end of the evening, we have about $1000 worth of prizes to give away. We will also open up for lightning talks if you have anything quick and interesting to share. Venue is at PLURALSIGHT (new location this time) Help us spread the word! (Because of the giveaways, we are asking each person to have a Meetup account and RSVP individually) Please message me with any dietary restrictions.

description:

He'll be answering questions and presenting as well. We'll serve Pizza provided by our sponsor, TEKSystems, at 6:30 P.M., the talk will start at 7 P.M.

name: IWD Party: "Speechless": The Art of Giving Awesome Presentations
description:
Hello friends! In light of International Women's Day, Women Techmakers has provided us with a slide deck filled with techniques and exercises used by the world-class improvisational performers and trainers called "Speechless". This will be a fun and highly interactive Meetup welcoming anyone who is interested in mastering the skills necessary to excel at public speaking. Please feel free to bring friends, family, or anybody interested in having a good time!

As per usual, we'll be serving Pizza provided by our sponsor, TEKSystems, at 6:30 P.M., and the presentation will start at 7 P.M.

The Google Development Group Salt Lake is sponsored by Google, Inc. and the meeting space is provided by HireVue, our sponsor.

description:
We have been extended a longer sponsorship from JetBrains, so we're going to practice our skills to celebrate. We'll go over rarely used features, helpful shortcuts, and other advanced features so that you can level up your in-IDE composing speed. New Location at Pluralsight in South Jordan!

We're trying out video streaming/recording at the meetup so join us from afar -> To join the meeting on a computer or mobile phone: https://bluejeans.com/1925308049?src=calendarLink

We'll serve Pizza provided by our sponsor, TEKSystems, at 6:30 P.M., the talk will start at 7 P.M.

The Google Development Group Salt Lake is sponsored by Google, Inc. and the meeting space is provided by Pluralsight, our new venue sponsor. JetBrains sponsors us with a monthly giveaway of premium access to one of their tools.

name: I/O Review and IoT hacknight
description:
We're going to do a brief recap of the biggest announcements from Google's I/O conference last month, and then will spend the rest of the time doing codelabs with 2 Android Things kits and a AIY Voice kit.
We'll serve Pizza provided by our sponsor, TEKSystems, at 6:30 P.M., the talk will start at 7 P.M.

We'll serve Pizza provided by our sponsor, TEKSystems, at 6:30 P.M., the talk will start at 7 P.M.

name: Build Assistant Actions on Google for Your Community
description:
If you have ever wanted to learn and practice creating actions or skills for a smart assistant, this is the workshop for you! Come join us for a day full of talks, codelabs, and actions showcasing. Learn how to build Actions for the Google Assistant that are useful for your community - whether it's a professional network, interest group, or your hometown. We'll be providing food, expert help, and some prizes for attendees. This is on a Saturday, so you can count on a focused group with lots of time for questions. You'll be able to walk away with a completed smart assistant action. All skill levels are welcome, even if you just have an idea!

We're charging to provide an excellent experience, and our organizers are volunteering their time, so no profit will be made.

Update:
We've received sponsorship from Apex Systems and are now offering a $50 AIY kit to the first 15 people to RSVP (and of course attend the event). We're continuing to talk to sponsors, so there's hopefully more to come! The AIY kits work using the same skills we'll learn and actions we build, so you'll be able to test and demonstrate your smart assistant talents anywhere! The day-long workshop includes breakfast and a catered lunch. We hope to be done by late-afternoon so you can still enjoy the rest of Saturday. The event is appropriate for all skill levels; we'll cover everything you need to know. You only need to bring a computer with a web browser, and we absolutely welcome any ideas for what kind of smart assistant action you want to build.
how_to_find_us: Please call on 385-528-8541 if you have trouble locating the building or getting access.

name: Cloud Next'18 Recap with Ryan Gifford
description:
Ryan Gifford will be sharing his takeaways from Google Next 2018, all the things dev-ops related as well as upcoming Istio integration into GCP (giving us SLO based metics, error budget reporting, canary deploys, etc). He will also talk about his experience using (and managing) Google Cloud Platform and some new things he is super excited about, like GKE on premise.

Ryan is a Senior Engineer at Solutionreach, focusing his efforts around the cloud platform in GCP. He drank the google kool-aid long ago and is currently in a long-term love affair with kubernetes. When the internet is down, he can be found riding motorcycles and building things. He currently lives in Eagle Mountain UT. https://www.linkedin.com/in/ryan-gifford-617b72

We'll serve Pizza provided by our sponsor, TEKSystems, at 6:30 P.M., the talk will start at 7 P.M.

The Google Development Group Salt Lake is sponsored by Google, Inc. and the meeting space is provided by Pluralsight, our sponsor. JetBrains provides a license for one attendee; drawing takes place at the end of the evening.
how_to_find_us: First floor, West side

name: Flutter Study Jam - Session 1
description:
Flutter is Google’s mobile app SDK for crafting high-quality native interfaces on iOS and Android in record time. Flutter is used by developers and organizations around the world, and is free and open source.

This session is our first of two sessions for our Flutter Study Jam, and we will be following material prepared by the Flutter team at Google. This is a hands-on session, so please bring a laptop!

If you want to hit the ground running, make sure you have Flutter installed on your laptop prior to starting the Study Jam. Windows/Linux/Mac are all fine. Check out : https://flutter.io/get-started/install/

---

We'll serve Pizza provided by our sponsor, TEKSystems, at 6:30 P.M., the event will start at 7 P.M.

The Google Development Group Salt Lake is sponsored by Google, Inc. and the meeting space is provided by Pluralsight, our sponsor. JetBrains provides a license for one attendee; drawing takes place at the end of the evening.

name: GDG Salt Lake DevFest 2018
description:
NOTE: DevFest'18 Registration is via Eventbrite only. Please RSVP here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/gdg-salt-lake-devfest-2018-tickets-51120690361

DevFest website is LIVE!! Check http://bit.ly/GDGSLCDevFest for more details about the speakers, agenda, sponsors, and much more.

About DevFest 2018:
GDG Salt Lake DevFest 2018 is our annual all-day developer conference that offers speaker sessions across multiple product areas, codelabs, hackathon and more! Come join the fun and learn about Mobile, Web, Cloud, Machine Learning, the Google Assistant, and IoT technologies.

Speakers:
There will be talks/workshops on AngularJS, Dart, Flutter, Machine Learning, React, Firebase, IoT, AMP, WebAuthN and professional development and much more. List of speakers: https://goo.gl/ZT4121

Corporate Sponsors:
Platinum Sponsor: Google Developers
Gold Sponsor: ConsultNET
Silver Sponsor: Solutionreach

There are still some corporate sponsorship positions available, so if your company is interested, please reach out us at [masked] or contact any of us organizers via meetup

Code of Conduct:
Be nice. Be respectful and constructive. Be collaborative. Participate. Be excellent to each other. Our code of conduct can be found​ here: https://goo.gl/Rt9V9S

FAQs
How can I contact the organizer with any questions?
You can reach out to us at [masked] or via meetup

What are my transportation/parking options for getting to and from the event?
There's free parking for the event. The venue is a walking distance from Lehi Frontrunner station.

name: Flutter Live
description:
Limited Space, please only RSVP if you will attend. Join us for Flutter Live on December 4th to experience the latest from Flutter, Google’s free and open source SDK for building high-quality native iOS and Android apps from a single codebase. Presented from the Science Museum in London, we are optimizing Flutter Live to reach the largest audience of mobile developers and provide all the rigor and excitement of an in-person experience to our global online audience. We're going to watch the keynote and talk about what the announcements mean for Flutter development. More info : https://developers.google.com/events/flutter-live/
We're also really excited to hear from Matt Rice, who recently released a paid app on both Android and iOS using Flutter. He'll talk about his experience and then we'll do some Q&A.

name: GDG Annual Holiday Party
description:
The GDG Org has given us some money to have a holiday party and thank our supporters. Agenda: food and prizes. Feel free to bring a project to work on, or questions to ask, or a lightning talk to present. It'll be very casual and a fun night.

The Google Development Group Salt Lake is sponsored by Google, Inc. and the meeting space is provided by HireVue, our sponsor. JetBrains provides a license for one attendee; drawing takes place at the end of the evening.

name: Open Project/hackathon Night
description: Come join us and work on a side-project, learn a new technology, or help someone else with their side projects. We'll have food and hope to give you the time you need to make the next great thing! Canopy (https://www.canopytax.com/) is opening their brand new building for us to be inspired by and this month we have Blue Raven Solar (https://blueravensolar.com/) sponsoring our food.

name: Ben Taylor - Chief AI Officer at Ziff.ai: FFMPEG for Deep-Learning Pipelines
description:
Ben Taylor is an AI enthusiast and has spent the last 4 years solving deep-learning problems for businesses. His experience ranges from defect localization in manufacturing to predicting the outcome of ABC's The Bachelor using AI. At this meetup Ben will discuss using FFMPEG to feed a deep-learning pipeline for automation. The focus of this meetup will be on streaming audio and video applications with AI. Ben will also discuss how he is using AI to manage a 7 camera home security system.

We'll serve Pizza provided by our sponsor, Nav Inc., at 6:00 P.M., the talk will start at 6:30 P.M.

Located on the 5th floor. Someone will be in the lobby to card you in.

The Google Development Group Salt Lake is sponsored by Google, Inc. and the meeting space is provided by Nav Inc., our sponsor. JetBrains provides a license for one attendee; drawing takes place at the end of the evening.

name: Google Assistant - Programing Google Home is fun and easy!
description:
Want to learn how to program a Google Home? Want to maybe walk away with a Google Home Mini?

Come on out for a presentation by Google Developer Expert and Google Developer Group Denver Organizer Mark Scheel covering Actions on Google programming.

Bring your laptop and be prepared to leave with all the tools you need to make an amazing voice interaction for yourself, your business or the world.

Mark has covered this topic before, recently at Droidcon Toronto in Canada (see event photo), and has spoken about other Google Developer topics in Paris, Hong Kong and major American cities like San Francisco, Los Angeles, Las Vegas, and Boston.

We're excited to have you, please tell your friends!

We'll serve Pizza provided by our sponsor, Nav, at 6:00 P.M., the talk will start at 6:30 P.M.
